definition: Half of a sphere, often referring to the Earth’s divisions.
example_sentence: “The Northern Hemisphere experiences winter while the Southern Hemisphere has summer.”

definition: Enabling a person to discover or learn something for themselves.
example_sentence: “The teacher used a heuristic approach to problem-solving.”

definition: Consisting of parts that are all of the same kind.
example_sentence: “The town had a relatively homogeneous population with shared cultural traditions.”

definition: Excessive pride or self-confidence.
example_sentence: “The general’s hubris led to a disastrous defeat.”

definition: A proposed explanation for a phenomenon.
example_sentence: “The scientist tested her hypothesis through a series of experiments.”

definition: Peculiar or individual in nature.
example_sentence: “His idiosyncratic way of speaking made him stand out in meetings.”

definition: To light up or clarify.
example_sentence: “The professor illuminated the complex theory with a simple analogy.”

definition: Extremely large or great.
example_sentence: “The ocean’s immense depth makes it difficult to explore.”

definition: Unchanging over time or unable to be changed.
example_sentence: “The laws of physics are considered immutable.”

definition: To communicate or make known.
example_sentence: “The mentor imparted valuable wisdom to his students.”

definition: Impossible to pass through or understand.
example_sentence: “The dense forest was nearly impenetrable.”

definition: Of vital importance; crucial.
example_sentence: “It is imperative that we address climate change immediately.”

definition: Impossible to perceive.
example_sentence: “The difference in weight was imperceptible to the touch.”

definition: Acting quickly without thought or care.
example_sentence: “His impetuous decision to quit his job surprised everyone.”

definition: A conclusion that can be drawn from something, though not explicitly stated.
example_sentence: “The implication of his statement was clear—he wanted a promotion.”

definition: Not exact or accurate.
example_sentence: “His instructions were too imprecise to be useful.”

definition: Not resulting from deliberate planning; unintentional.
example_sentence: “His inadvertent mistake cost the company thousands.”

definition: Without intention; accidentally.
example_sentence: “She inadvertently deleted an important file from her computer.”

definition: A thing that motivates or encourages someone to do something.
example_sentence: “The company offered bonuses as an incentive for employees to work overtime.”

definition: Not leading to a firm conclusion.
example_sentence: “The test results were inconclusive and required further analysis.”

definition: A state of being out of place or inconsistent.
example_sentence: “The incongruity of his casual outfit at the formal event was noticeable.”

definition: Not in harmony or keeping with the surroundings.
example_sentence: “His bright red shoes were incongruous with his otherwise formal attire.”

definition: The state of not being easily seen or noticed.
example_sentence: “The spy relied on his inconspicuousness to blend into the crowd.”

definition: Impossible to read or understand.
example_sentence: “The ancient script was indecipherable without the help of linguists.”

definition: Impossible to remove, forget, or erase.
example_sentence: “The tragic event left an indelible mark on her memory.”

definition: Not exactly known, established, or defined.
example_sentence: “The cause of the explosion remains indeterminate.”

definition: To bring about or cause something to happen.
example_sentence: “The doctor used medication to induce sleep.”

definition: Too great or extreme to be expressed in words.
example_sentence: “The beauty of the sunset was ineffable.”

definition: Not producing the desired effect.
example_sentence: “The negotiations were ineffectual, leading to a continued stalemate.”

definition: Certain to happen; unavoidable.
example_sentence: “With the rising costs, price increases seemed inevitable.”

definition: Impossible to stop or prevent.
example_sentence: “The passage of time is inexorable.”

definition: To deduce or conclude from evidence and reasoning.
example_sentence: “From her tone, he infers that she was upset.”

definition: Existing as a natural or essential characteristic.
example_sentence: “The risks of surgery are inherent to the procedure.”

definition: Serving to slow down or restrain a process.
example_sentence: “The drug has an inhibitory effect on nerve signals.”

definition: Impossible to satisfy.
example_sentence: “His insatiable curiosity led him to read every book in the library.”

definition: Having deep understanding or perception.
example_sentence: “Her insightful comments added depth to the discussion.”

definition: Lacking flavor, interest, or vigor.
example_sentence: “The lecture was insipid, putting the students to sleep.”

definition: Filled with creativity or motivation.
example_sentence: “His inspired speech moved the audience.”

definition: Isolated or having a narrow viewpoint.
example_sentence: “The small town had an insular culture, resistant to change.”

definition: Essential or necessary for completeness.
example_sentence: “A good education is integral to success.”

definition: An explanation or understanding of something.
example_sentence: “His interpretation of the poem differed from hers.”

definition: Closely connected or twisted together.
example_sentence: “Their lives became intertwined after years of friendship.”

definition: Unwilling to change one’s views or agree.
example_sentence: “The two sides remained intransigent during negotiations.”

definition: Very detailed and complicated.
example_sentence: “The artist’s intricate designs took months to complete.”

definition: Belonging naturally; essential.
example_sentence: “The intrinsic value of gold makes it a desirable asset.”

definition: Creative and original.
example_sentence: “The scientist was known for his inventive problem-solving skills.”

definition: To call upon or refer to something.
example_sentence: “The speech invokes themes of justice and equality.”

definition: Without conscious control.
example_sentence: “She involuntarily gasped at the shocking news.”

definition: To place side by side for contrast.
example_sentence: “The artist juxtaposed dark colors with bright ones to create contrast.”

definition: The act of placing things next to each other for contrast.
example_sentence: “The juxtaposition of poverty and wealth in the city was striking.”

definition: Missing or deficient in some way.
example_sentence: “His argument was lacking evidence to support his claim.”

definition: To express sorrow or regret.
example_sentence: “She lamented the loss of her childhood home.”

definition: Existing but not yet developed or visible.
example_sentence: “His latent talent for painting emerged later in life.”

definition: Conforming to laws, rules, or accepted standards.
example_sentence: “The business had a legitimate claim to the property.”

definition: Clear and easy to understand.
example_sentence: “Her explanation was so lucid that even a beginner could grasp the concept.”

definition: The emission of light by a substance not resulting from heat.
example_sentence: “The jellyfish glowed with an eerie luminescence in the dark waters.”

definition: Generous, forgiving, or noble in spirit.
example_sentence: “Despite their rivalry, she was magnanimous in victory.”

definition: Easily shaped, influenced, or adaptable.
example_sentence: “Gold is highly malleable and can be hammered into thin sheets.”

definition: An outward or visible expression of something.
example_sentence: “The rising tensions were a manifestation of deeper social issues.”

definition: Pleasantly smooth and musical to hear.
example_sentence: “The singer’s mellifluous voice captivated the audience.”

definition: Subject to sudden or unpredictable changes.
example_sentence: “His mercurial temperament made him difficult to work with.”

definition: Extremely careful and precise.
example_sentence: “She was meticulous in organizing her research notes.”

definition: Disliking or avoiding human society.
example_sentence: “The misanthropic old man rarely spoke to his neighbors.”

definition: To make less severe or serious.
example_sentence: “The government took measures to mitigate the effects of the crisis.”

definition: To adjust or regulate to a certain level or standard.
example_sentence: “He modulated his voice to sound more authoritative.”

definition: Extremely large, significant, or important.
example_sentence: “The discovery was a monumental achievement in the field of medicine.”

definition: Related to the form or structure of things.
example_sentence: “The morphological differences between species help scientists classify them.”

definition: Having many aspects or dimensions.
example_sentence: “Her research took a multifaceted approach to solving the problem.”

definition: Ordinary, lacking excitement, or routine.
example_sentence: “He found his office job mundane and uninspiring.”

definition: Very generous.
example_sentence: “The munificent donor contributed millions to the university.”

definition: Just beginning to develop.
example_sentence: “The nascent technology showed great promise.”

definition: Vague, unclear, or ill-defined.
example_sentence: “His explanation was too nebulous to be understood.”

definition: Existing in name only, or very small in amount.
example_sentence: “He was the nominal leader, but the real power lay elsewhere.”

definition: New, original, or different from anything seen before.
example_sentence: “Her novel approach to the problem impressed her colleagues.”

definition: The quality of being new, original, or unusual.
example_sentence: “The novelty of the invention attracted a lot of attention.”

definition: Characterized by subtle distinctions or variations.
example_sentence: “Her argument was well-structured and highly nuanced.”

definition: Stubbornly refusing to change one’s opinion or course of action.
example_sentence: “Despite the evidence, he remained obdurate in his stance.”

definition: To make something unclear or difficult to understand.
example_sentence: “The lawyer tried to obfuscate the details of the case.”

definition: Indirect or not straightforward.
example_sentence: “His oblique answer made it hard to determine his true intentions.”

definition: Not well known or difficult to understand.
example_sentence: “The professor referenced an obscure 18th-century philosopher.”

definition: Excessively submissive or eager to please.
example_sentence: “The obsequious assistant praised her boss at every opportunity.”

definition: No longer in use or out of date.
example_sentence: “VCRs have become obsolete with the rise of streaming services.”

definition: Stubbornly refusing to change one’s mind.
example_sentence: “The child was obstinate about not eating his vegetables.”

definition: Noticeable in an unwelcome or intrusive way.
example_sentence: “His loud behavior was obtrusive in the quiet library.”

definition: Something unusual or strange.
example_sentence: “The sculpture was an oddity that puzzled many visitors.”

definition: Burdensome or involving great effort.
example_sentence: “The new regulations placed onerous demands on small businesses.”

definition: Not transparent or difficult to understand.
example_sentence: “The explanation was so opaque that few people grasped the concept.”

definition: Functioning or having an effect.
example_sentence: “Only the last clause of the contract is operative.”

definition: Rich and luxurious.
example_sentence: “The palace was decorated in an opulent style.”

definition: Stated or appearing to be true, but not necessarily so.
example_sentence: “His ostensible purpose was to help, but he had ulterior motives.”

definition: Apparently or supposedly.
example_sentence: “She was ostensibly on a business trip, but she was actually on vacation.”

definition: Showy or designed to impress.
example_sentence: “The millionaire’s ostentatious display of wealth included gold-plated furniture.”

definition: Comprehensive or all-encompassing.
example_sentence: “The overarching theme of the novel was redemption.”
